abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, with an unlikely sustainability. Although
            the Bank performance is rated satisfactory, its handling of
            project execution was too permissive regarding compliance
            with legal covenants, and audit requirements, reflected in
            the Borrower's deficient performance, whose repeated
            breaches of loan covenants, included the resettlement
            failure (despite availability of resources), failure to
            replenish the special account, and reluctance to follow
            procurement guidelines. Lessons mostly address the
            importance of building stakeholders' commitment, and
            ownership, and, designing sound institutional setup early
            on. Identified reforms to improve urban sector management,
            but relinquished in favor of civil works, confirms the
            absence of Government commitment, an issue which should be
            agreed prior to loan effectiveness. Furthermore, the
            ambitious sector program, featuring a combination of
            physical, and institutional elements, but not consistently
            linked because of weak strategies and unclear prioritization
            of actions, hindered even the usually successful physical
            components. In addition, implementation arrangements -
            critical at project design, and key conditions to project
            success - and, performance indicators, were insufficiently
            considered, which diverted decision-making, and weakened
            project monitoring, respectively.
